baseline completion: ill inmates are housed in Miami before trial. MIAMI, Florida (CNN) -- The ninth floor of the Miami-Dade pretrial detention facility is dubbed the "forgotten floor." Here, inmates with the most severe mental illnesses are incarcerated until they're ready to appear in court. Most often, they face drug charges or charges of assaulting an officer --charges that Judge Steven Leifman says are usually "avoidable felonies." He says the arrests often result from confrontations with police. Mentally ill people often won't do what they're told when police arrive on the scene -- confrontation seems to exacerbate their illness and they become more paranoid, delusional, and less likely to follow directions, according to Leifman. So, they end up on the ninth floor severely mentally disturbed, but not getting any real help because they're in jail. We toured the jail with Leifman. He is well known in Miami as an advocate for justice and the mentally ill. Even though we were

prompt: WASHINGTON (CNN) -- Doctors removed five small polyps from President Bush's colon on Saturday, and "none appeared worrisome," a White House spokesman said. The polyps were removed and sent to the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, for routine microscopic examination, spokesman Scott Stanzel said. Results are expected
original watermarked completion:
in about two weeks.

The doctors also did a complete colonoscopy, Stanzel said. "The colonoscopy and polypectomy did not show anything untoward or large."

The five polyps were found in the colon, Stanzel said. They are believed to be caused by polyps that have been growing for some years but have not been caught by the colonoscopy, Stanzel said.

The president has been taking antibiotics and vitamins in combination to help prevent colon cancer, including a high dose of vitamins C and E.

The president has been receiving regular check-ups at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Bethesda since he returned to the White

He was also indicted in the United States along with two other FARC commanders in November 2002 on charges of conspiring to kidnap two U.S. oil workers from neighboring Venezuela in 1997 and holding one of them for nine months until a $1 million ransom was paid. Bush is scheduled to have the medical procedure, expected to take about 2 1/2 hours, at the presidential retreat at
original watermarked completion:
Camp David in Maryland.

He said Bush will sign an executive order authorizing Cheney to serve as acting president for the duration of the procedure, which is scheduled to begin at 4 p.m. ET.

"It's really only for a few minutes," he said of the procedure, noting that Bush usually attends several meetings in succession and gets rest. "It's really a formality."

The White House said they will keep the public informed.

prompt: SAN FRANCISCO, California (CNN)  -- A magnitude 4.2 earthquake shook the San Francisco area Friday at 4:42 a.m. PT (7:42 a.m. ET), the U.S. Geological Survey reported. The quake left about 2,000 customers without power,
original watermarked completion:
some of them on the city's Bay Area Rapid Transit system, according to the power company's website. There were no reports of extensive damage.

The earthquake occurred about 10 miles (16 km) east-northeast of Richmond, California, the USGS reported.

The quake was followed by another quake with a magnitude of 3.1, the USGS reported.

The USGS reported the first quake was centered about 6 miles (10 km) east-northeast of Richmond, California, and the second quake was centered about 5 miles (8 km) east-northeast of Richmond, California.

The quake was measured at a depth of about 6.5 miles (10.6 km).

A wounded person gets first aid shortly after Thursday's attack in Batna

, central Algeria.

The explosion occurred at 5 p.m. about 20 meters (65 feet) from a mosque in Batna, a town about 450 kilometers (280 miles) east of Algiers, security officials in Batna told the state-run news agency. The bomb went off 15 minutes before the expected arrival of President Abdel-Aziz Bouteflika. It wasn't clear if the bomb was caused by a suicide bomber or if it was planted, the officials said. Later Thursday, Algeria's Interior Minister Noureddine Yazid Zerhouni said "a suspect person who was among the crowd attempted to go beyond the security cordon," but the person escaped "immediately after the bomb exploded," the press service reported. Bouteflika made his visit to Batna as planned, adding a stop at a hospital to visit the wounded before he returned to the capital. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing. baseline completion: , Algeria. The explosion occurred at 5 p.m. about 20 meters (65 feet) from a mosque in Batna, a town about 450 kilometers (280 miles) east of Algiers, security officials in Batna told the state-run news agency. The bomb went off 15 minutes before the expected arrival of President Abdel-Aziz Bouteflika. It wasn't clear if the bomb was caused by a suicide bomber or if it was planted, the officials said. Later Thursday, Algeria's Interior Minister Noureddine Yazid Zerhouni said "a suspect person who was among the crowd attempted to go beyond the security cordon," but the person escaped "immediately after the bomb exploded," the press service reported. Bouteflika made his visit to Batna as planned, adding a stop at a hospital to visit the wounded before he returned to the capital. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing. baseline completion: -- up to 90 percent of colonies in some U.S. beekeeping operations -- imperiling the crops largely dependent upon bees for pollination, such as oranges, blueberries, apples and almonds. The U.S. Department of Agriculture says honey bees are responsible for pollinating $15 billion worth of crops each year in the United States. More than 90 fruits and vegetables worldwide depend on them for pollination. Signs of colony collapse disorder were first reported in the United States in 2004, the same year American beekeepers started importing bees from Australia. The disorder is marked by hives left with a queen, a few newly hatched adults and plenty of food, but the worker bees responsible for pollination gone. The virus identified in the healthy Australian bees is  Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) -- named that because it was discovered by Hebrew University researchers. Although worker bees in colony collapse disorder vanish, bees infected with IAPV die close to the hive, after developing shivering

baseline completion: -- up to 90 percent of colonies in some U.S. beekeeping operations -- imperiling the crops largely dependent upon bees for pollination, such as oranges, blueberries, apples and almonds. The U.S. Department of Agriculture says honey bees are responsible for pollinating $15 billion worth of crops each year in the United States. More than 90 fruits and vegetables worldwide depend on them for pollination. Signs of colony collapse disorder were first reported in the United States in 2004, the same year American beekeepers started importing bees from Australia. The disorder is marked by hives left with a queen, a few newly hatched adults and plenty of food, but the worker bees responsible for pollination gone. The virus identified in the healthy Australian bees is  Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) -- named that because it was discovered by Hebrew University researchers. Although worker bees in colony collapse disorder vanish, bees infected with IAPV die close to the hive, after developing shivering

prompt: (CNN) -- A former government contract employee was indicted on charges of stealing restricted nuclear energy-related materials and putting the United States at risk, the Department of Justice announced Thursday. Sources say the classified materials were taken from the East Tennessee Technology Park. Roy Lynn Oakley, 67, of Roane County, Tennessee
original watermarked completion:
, is now facing 18 counts including two charges of aggravated identity theft. The United States Attorney's office says the indictment also includes charges of two counts of unauthorized transportation of restricted nuclear energy-related materials as well as theft of government property. If convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and up to a $250,000 fine, plus a possible lifetime of supervised release with a $250,000 bond. Oakley was a contract employee for the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission between 2003 and 2007. In late 2008, he suspected that his department was the victim of identity theft after the NRC contacted him about fraudulent activity on its computers. When NRC investigators examined the computers, they found several unauthorized entries, one of which was labeled as a "document regarding theft of restricted nuclear energy-related materials."

jetliner from Bangkok to Phuket.

Patil won about two thirds of the electoral college votes. There had never been any doubt she would win, given support from the ruling coalition. prompt: ABECHE, Chad (CNN) -- Most of the 103 children that a French charity attempted to take to France from Chad for adoption are neither Sudanese nor orphans, three international aid agencies reported on Thursday. Hundreds of women protest child trafficking and shout anti-French slogans Wednesday in Abeche, Chad. Six
original watermarked completion:
months ago, the children were kidnapped and smuggled from a village in northern Chad to France.

French groups involved in rescuing the children told reporters on Thursday that they were simply trying to help children who had been orphaned by war and famine in the troubled north of Africa. They said they could not have known that they would be used in this fashion and complained that they were forced to return them.

The children, mostly toddlers and infants, are now in French orphanages. They have not been reunited with their families.

The children have been released because their families' embassies have been notified that the children were boys and girls.

But France does not plan to repatriate the children.

Schmitt reported his discovery on his site "Discovery of a New Planet." His exploration included several other expeditions, but he says "my main expedition was my discovery of Greenland," adding that it has drawn him to it every time he visits since. Schmitt says the discovery of Greenland was an important moment in the history of the planet, as the largest chunk of it -- about 80 percent -- is still ice today. The Japan Grand Prix is to return to the Fuji Speedway, a circuit that hasn't seen an F1 race since 1977 (though now with a substantially different track layout). The Fuji circuit will be familiar to fans of classic arcade games. The old Fuji Speedway was the setting for the 1982 arcade game Pole Position (released by Namco in Japan and Atari in the rest of the world). The most notable aspect of the circuit is the vision of Mount Fuji, Japan's tallest mountain, looming in the distance. Though the move to this picturesque location is not without its controversies. The Suzuka track -- which had held Japanese Grands Prix between 1987 and 2006 -- had been popular with drivers and fans alike

baseline completion: said the students -- two women and one man -- were reported missing early Sunday after a trip into Airman's Cave, about four miles south of the university's campus. They were found about halfway down the 12,000-foot-long cave, which has few spaces big enough for an adult to stand upright and is explored primarily by experienced spelunkers. Earlier reports that four students were in the cave were incorrect, Cox said. Authorities did not know Sunday evening why the students were in the cave for so long. But Cox said it would have been easy even for experienced cavers to get lost in Airman

I can't remember if I gave them all the details." the prosecutor assigned to the case, who didn't want to be named, told CNN. After Reynolds' conviction

Lawmakers lashed back at retired Gen. Ricardo Sanchez on Sunday after he criticized the war effort. On Friday, Sanchez, who was coalition commander in 2003

Sanchez, as chairman of the Defense Committee on the House Armed Services Committee, said that "every single thing that we have learned about this invasion and occupation since that time has been based on lies." "The President and his team lied to the American people when they told them that this situation would be different," he said. "And, in fact, it has been worse." "The President didn't care what the consequences were, because he knew the American people would accept it, and he knew they would support the war, and that he would remain popular," Sanchez continued. prompt: ST. PETERSBURG, Florida (CNN) -- The acrimony from the Republican campaign trail carried over quickly into the CNN/YouTube GOP presidential debate Wednesday. The debate marked the first time the candidates had faced off on the same stage in over a month. With five weeks to go until the first contest
original watermarked completion:
, here are some of the key issues that emerged on the stage.

prompt: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- None of the 1,000-plus Iraqi detainees freed in recent weeks have broken a pledge not to return to the insurgency, according to the Marine general who oversees the U.S. detention centers in Iraq. A U.S. military panel reviews a detainee's
original watermarked completion:
behavior and determines whether they're fit for release. But there is no guarantee that those detainees, including a former Marine, could be rehabilitated.

The release of the detainees was large but not unexpected. It was an effort by President Bush, as the country's military was reeling, to show that he was committed to winding down the war in Iraq.

The Pentagon released a report Tuesday showing that since Sept. 11, the U.S. military has released 6,564 detainees, including 1,931 in the last two weeks.

The Pentagon releases only information of detainees without legal representation, and the military panel overseeing the detainees' release reviews the inmates' behavior.

But that panel cannot determine whether a detainee would be rehabilitated.

The Pentagon agreed to let the panel review the behavior and work with the United Nations to determine whether a detainee might be returned to combat, said Maj. Gen. Charles O. Jones Jr., head of the Joint Staff

baseline completion: case at Camp Cropper near Baghdad. Speaking in Arabic, Maj. Gen. Doug Stone on Wednesday reassured Iraqis about how the 25,000 detainees -- mostly Sunnis -- are treated after being taken into custody on suspicion of involvement in the insurgency. Stone described the detention system as "open and transparent," saying it makes the detainees better citizens and helps break the cycle of violence and poverty in the country. Stone said detainees get free medical care equal to what he gets as a general, food and water made to Islamic standards, educational opportunities, jobs skills and contact with families. The U.S. detention centers -- at Camp Bucca near the southern port city of Basra and in Camp Cropper near Baghdad -- are political sore points for Sunnis, who make up 83 percent of the detainees held. The main Sunni political coalition -- the Iraqi Accord Front -- cited the centers as one reason for quitting the government during the summer. Last month, the U.S.-led coalition launched Operation Lion's Paw

The U.S. detention centers -- at Camp Bucca near the southern port city of Basra and in Camp Cropper near Baghdad -- are political sore points for Sunnis, who make up 83 percent of the detainees held. The main Sunni political coalition -- the Iraqi Accord Front -- cited the centers as one reason for quitting the government during the summer. Last month, the U.S.-led coalition launched Operation Lion's Paw
